fields.description: This is same as HADOOP-7154 but for yarn. RM, NM, AM and containers should all have this.
fields.summary: Should set MALLOC_ARENA_MAX for all YARN daemons and AMs/Containers

comments.body:
Arun says in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MAPREDUCE-3065 that the NM should be modified to do this.

Based on poking around, it appears that bin/yarn-config.sh is a better place to do this, as it then makes it into the RM, NM, and the Container from there (given that the container launch context gets the env variables from its parent process, the NM).

Does anyone have an argument for not doing it in yarn-config.sh? Already tested locally, and it appears to work.
tested locally. pmap without this is 2g vmem. pmap with this is 1.3 gig vmem. echo'ing env variable makes it through to the AM and containers.

Chris, setting this in yarn-default.sh will work for RM/NM itself.

However, the containers don't inherit NM's environment - thus we'll need to explicitly do it. Take a look at ContainerLaunch.sanitizeEnv. 

To be more general we need to add a notion of 'admin env' so admins can set MALLOC_ARENA_MAX and others automatically for all containers.

Makes sense?
Think so. Regarding admin env, are you saying an admin-env.sh file (similar to hadoop-env.sh)?

No, not another *-env.sh file.

It's simpler to make it configurable via yarn-site.xml.

Add a yarn.nodemanager.admin-env config which takes 'key=value','key=value' etc.

There is similar functionality for MR applications - take a look at MRJobConfig.MAPRED_ADMIN_USER_ENV and how it's used in MapReduceChildJVM.setEnv which uses MRApps.setEnvFromInputString. Maybe you can move MRApps.setEnvFromInputString to yarn-common and use it.
Tested locally.
Patch to allow environment variables to be set for containers. Use case is for MALLOC_ARENA_MAX.

-1 overall.  Here are the results of testing the latest attachment 
  http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12496943/MAPREDUCE-3068.diff
  against trunk revision .

    +1 @author.  The patch does not contain any @author tags.

    -1 tests included.  The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
                        Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
                        Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

    +1 javadoc.  The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

    +1 javac.  The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

    +1 findbugs.  The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

    +1 release audit.  The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

    +1 core tests.  The patch passed unit tests in .

    +1 contrib tests.  The patch passed contrib unit tests.

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-MAPREDUCE-Build/886//testReport/
Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-MAPREDUCE-Build/886//console

This message is automatically generated.
Any feedback on this?

Thanks for taking this up!

Gone through the patch, some comments:
 - Now that the configuration is getting added for NM white-list of envs, I think we can close MAPREDUCE-2748 as duplicate and use this same configuration for passing HADOOP_CONF_DIR, JAVA_HOME, HADOOP_COMMON_HOME, HADOOP_HDFS_HOME, YARN_HOME to the containers. The defaults can still fall back to the values from NM Env. What do you think?
 - Need to add the new configuration to yarn-default.xml
 - Also, helps to have a couple of tests for this to verify that the configured values for the NM are getting passed to the containers.

Per Vinod's comment. Added a unit test that verifies that MALLOC_ARENA_MAX gets passed through to the container. Also, added default pass through for all of the HADOOP_*, YARN_*, and JAVA_HOME environment variables. Added yarn-default.xml settings as well as YarnConfiguration settings.

Seems to be working.

Chris - this looks great, thanks for the nice refactor to use it in both NM and MR apps.

One nit is that we want the 'putIfAbsent' semantics i.e. allow containers to override HADOOP_*_HOME etc. Could you please fix it? 

Also, can you please look at the javadoc warnings? 

Thanks!

Hey Arun,

Are you talking about the putIfAbsent stuff that I removed in the sanitizeEnv function?

I'll have a look at the javadoc stuff.

Thanks!
Chris
Yep, the putIfAbsent semantics are important since we want to allow containers to set an alternate HADOOP_*_HOME. Does that make sense? Thanks.
changing back to putIfAbsent

Hey Arun,

Do you want just the putIfAbsent vars specified in the latest patch, or do you want to modify setEnvFromInputString to putIfAbsent for ALL env variables specified in admin-env? I have some concern about doing the latter, as it changes the existing behavior of the setEnv.. method, which is used in MR, not just YARN.

Thanks!
Chris
Waiting on Arun to figure out behavior of addToEnvironment.. whether we should change to addToEnvironmentIfBasent
Latest attachment now uses putIfAbsent logic for container environment variables that are supplied via admin-env property.
Submitting patch.

Turns out MR was using addToEnvironment, so enabled old API plus new API with overwrite param.

Chris - we should allow applications to override JAVA_HOME, HADOOP_COMMON_HOME, HADOOP_HDFS_HOME and YARN_HOME. Thus, we want the putIfAbsent semantics when we are setting them from either the NodeManager's environment or from the admin.env.

Does that make sense? Thanks.

Hey Arun,

Could you have a look at the patch I just put up? It uses putIfAbsent from sanitizeEnv -> setEnvFromInputStringIfAbsent -> addToEnvironment. That way, any env variables set via admin-env will only be applied if they aren't already set in the environment.

This should allow apps to override the variables, I believe.

I thought it was a little goofy to have putIfAbsent specifically called out for certain env variables and not for others, so I put them all in admin-env, and made all admin-env variables putIfAbsent. That way it covers both the env variables that you list out, as well as any other variables that someone may add.

Is this OK?

Cheers,
Chris

I think that makes sense. Thanks. 

I'll review your patch once more and commit.

Oh wait, on second thoughts... (sorry, you aren't going to like it)

I think we want a whitelist of stuff apps can override (MAPREDUCE-2784). Thus we allow only those to be overridable and everything else on admin.env shouldn't be.

Hope that makes sense, sorry again!

Sorry, that ref. should have been MAPREDUCE-2748 which tracks a 'whitelist'.

As Vinod mentioned earlier, we can close that as a dup of this one once we add the whitelist too. Makes sense?

Hey Arun,

Just to clarify, basically, you want what I had before, right?

Essentially, admin-env never over-writes, and we have hard coded putIfAbsent calls in sanitizeEnv for specific variables (JAVA_HOME, HADOOP_COMMON_HOME, HADOOP_HDFS_HOME and YARN_HOME)

Cheers,
Chris

Yep, that will work. 

Even better - add a whitelist config key instead of hardcoding the 4 env vars... I'd prefer that if you don't mind.

I was worried you would say that. ;)

Give me 10 mins.
Thanks Chris! Really appreciate your patience... :)

OK! There are now two configs:

admin-env

env-whitelist

Any settings in admin-env will be passed from the node manager to the container.

Any variable name listed in env-whitelist will only pass forward the settings from the NodeManager if the container has not ALREADY specified a value.
Triggering hudson build.

+1, looks good. Thanks Chris!

I'll commit after I get the go ahead from Mr. Hudson.

Chris,
 One more Minor nit :)
 Your latest patch does not have the Apache licence grant check. You'd have to re upload the patch with the license granted.

OK, so now there's some test job monitor failure going off. Trunk doesn't seem very stable at this point. Especially given https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MAPREDUCE-3195

Is there an easy way to run trunk without my patch so that we can properly diff it?

Also, the test failure is coming from:

TestJobMonitorAndPrint.java

    Layout layout =
        Logger.getRootLogger().getAppender("stdout").getLayout();

This doesn't have much to do with me. Same thing with the FindBugs stuff. I poked around the javac warnings and I think it's getting confused because of a cast in TestContainerLaunch that's not part of my code.

Cheers,
Chris

The last run of my job that didn't fail with this testjobmonitorandprint issue was four runs ago. Immediately after:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MAPREDUCE-3003

I started seeing the testjobmonitorandprint failures.
Hudson tests appear to be messed up. Triaging.
Adding a do-nothing patch to see how stable trunk is right now.
I ran this patch on a secure cluster and saw no issues.
